channel.title: DARIAH-Campus
channel.description: DARIAH-Campus is a discovery framework and hosting platform for DARIAH learning resources.

item.title: Automatic Text Recognition (ATR) - Step 2: Where and How to Get Images
item.dc:creator: Anna Busch, David Lassner, Aneta Plzáková
item.description: This tutorial explores where and how to find, create, and collect images of textual material, a crucial initial step in any process using Automatic Text Recognition (ATR).

item.title: Linking Digital Heritage, Games and Virtual Tourism
item.dc:creator: Erik Champion
item.description: This talk gives an overview over developments in digital cultural heritage in recent decades and explores challenges, and opportunities, in the field. It addresses the importance of open, fair and democratic sharing of cultural data, challenges with sustainability of digital projects and how gaming can be a tool for public engagement.

item.title: Historical Farm and People Registry in Iceland – Turning static list entries into network nodes
item.dc:creator: Pétur Húni Björnsson
item.description: This presentation outlines the aim and scope of the Historical Farm and People Registry project, explains the development process and problems encountered on the way, and demonstrates a use case for the ‘final’ product.

item.title: Making an Interactive Web Application with R and Shiny
item.dc:creator: Yann Ryan
item.description: This lesson demonstrates how to build a basic interactive web application using Shiny, a library (a set of additional functions) for the programming language R. In the lesson, you will design and implement a simple application, consisting of a slider which allows a user to select a date range, which will then trigger some code in R, and display a set of corresponding points on an interactive map.

item.title: Automatic Text Recognition (ATR) - Step 1: Getting Started
item.dc:creator: Ariane Pinche, Pauline Spychala
item.description: Kick off your journey into Automatic Text Recognition (ATR) with our introductory tutorial video. This is the first video of a tutorial series dedicated to extracting full text from scanned images.

item.title: Chroma Key Tutorial
item.dc:creator: Romain Herault, Emily Hanscam
item.description: This tutorial provides a comprehensive guide on using chroma keying, or green screen effects, with the PowerDirector video editing app, showing users how to set up the app, import footage, apply the chroma key effect, and export the final video.

item.title: Scalable Reading of Structured Data
item.dc:creator: Max Odsbjerg Pedersen, Josephine Møller Jensen, Victor Harbo Johnston, Alexander Ulrich Thygesen, Helle Strandgaard Jensen
item.description: In this lesson, you will be introduced to ‘scalable reading’ and how to apply this workflow to your analysis of structured data.

item.title: Introduction to Map Warper
item.dc:creator: Anthony Picón Rodríguez, Miguel Cuadros
item.description: This lesson from Programming Historian introduces basic use of Map Warper for historical maps. It guides you from upload to export, demonstrating methods for georeferencing and producing visualizations.

item.title: Diamond Publication and Open Science at ULiège
item.dc:creator: Bernard Pochet
item.description: In this video, presented as part of the Friday Frontiers series, Bernard Pochet traces the evolution of Open Science at the University of Liège in the early 2000s, focusing on Open Access and the implementation of a Diamond Open Access journal publishing platform (PoPuPS) and an institutional repository (ORBi).

item.title: Interrogating a National Narrative with GPT-2
item.dc:creator: Chantal Brousseau
item.description: In this lesson, you will learn how to apply a Generative Pre-trained Transformer language model to a large-scale corpus so that you can locate broad themes and trends within written text.

item.title: The CLS INFRA Survey of Methods in Computational Literary Studies
item.dc:creator: Christof Schöch, Julia Dudar, Evegniia Fileva
item.description: This resource from the CLS INFRA project offers an introduction to several research areas and issues that are prominent withinComputational Literary Studies (CLS), including authorship attribution, literary history, literary genre, gender in literature, and canonicity/prestige, as well as to several key methodological concerns that are of importance when performing research in CLS.

item.title: Photogrammetry Tutorial
item.dc:creator: Romain Herault, Emily Hanscam
item.description: This tutorial introduces the concept of photogrammetry and its application using the Kiri Engine, a 3D scanner app, guiding users through the process of preparing an object for scanning, capturing photos, and using Kiri Engine to create a 3D model.

item.title: Computer Vision for the Humanities: An Introduction to Deep Learning for Image Classification (Part 1)
item.dc:creator: Daniel van Strien, Kaspar Beelen, Melvin Wevers, Thomas Smits, Katherine McDonough
item.description: This is the first of a two-part lesson introducing deep learning based computer vision methods for humanities research. Using a dataset of historical newspaper advertisements and the fastai Python library, the lesson walks through the pipeline of training a computer vision model to perform image classification.

item.title: Computer Vision for the Humanities: An Introduction to Deep Learning for Image Classification (Part 2)
item.dc:creator: Daniel van Strien, Kaspar Beelen, Melvin Wevers, Thomas Smits, Katherine McDonough
item.description: This is the second of a two-part lesson introducing deep learning based computer vision methods for humanities research. This lesson digs deeper into the details of training a deep learning based computer vision model. It covers some challenges one may face due to the training data used and the importance of choosing an appropriate metric for your model. It presents some methods for evaluating the performance of a model.

item.title: Regression Analysis with Scikit-learn (part 2 - Logistic)
item.dc:creator: Matthew J Lavin
item.description: This lesson is the second in a two-part lesson focusing on regression analysis. It provides an overview of logistic regression, how to use Python (Scikit-learn) to make a logistic regression model, and a discussion of interpreting the results of such analysis.

item.title: Bridging the Sensory Gaps - Innovations for Inclusivity
item.dc:creator: Nasrine Olson
item.description: How would you as a person with deafblindness navigate the world – a world filled with navigation and mobility challenges, inaccessible information, and technologies that rely on the senses of sight and hearing? In this talk, Nasrine Olson (PhD, Associate Professor) introduces the idea behind the formation of the Centre for Inclusive Studies at University of Borås and presents a few projects that have explored ways in which technology can be leveraged to level the playing field.

item.title: Regression Analysis with Scikit-Learn (part 1 - Linear)
item.dc:creator: Matthew J Lavin
item.description: This lesson is the first of a two-part lesson focusing on an indispensable set of data analysis methods, logistic and linear regression. It provides an overview of linear regression and walks through running both algorithms in Python (using Scikit-learn). The lesson also discusses interpreting the results of a regression model and some common pitfalls to avoid.

item.title: Displaying a Georeferenced Map in KnightLab's StoryMap JS
item.dc:creator: Erica Y Hayes, Mia Partlow
item.description: In this lesson from Programming Historian, you will learn how to display a georeferenced map from Map Warper in KnightLab's StoryMap JS, an interactive web-based map and storytelling platform.

item.title: New Readers for Old Texts: Sharing the Workflow of a Digitally Enriched Children Literature Edition
item.dc:creator: Maria Goicoechea
item.description: Digitised formats are immensely valuable for researchers but may seem dry and unappealing to broader audiences, particularly when the original content was intended for children. This talk presents the preliminary research conducted on digitised formats of popular children's literature found in specialised libraries.

item.title: Finding Places in Text with the World Historical Gazetteer
item.dc:creator: Susan Grunewald, Andrew Janco
item.description: Researchers often need to be able to search a corpus of texts for a defined list of terms and historians are often interested in certain places named in a text or texts. This lesson details how to programmatically search documents for a list of terms, including place names and then how to obtain coordinates and map historical place names with the World Historical Gazetteer.
